bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 161, Number 72 (Tuesday, May 12, 2015)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. ROHRABACHER:H.R. 2263.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8, Clause 3:The Congress shall have power to regulate commerce withforeign nations, and among the several states, and withIndian tribes.andArticle I, Section 8, Clause 18:The Congress shall have power to make all Laws which shallbe necessary and proper for carrying into Execution theforegoing Powers, and all other Powers vested by thisConstitution in the Government of the United States, or inany Department of Officer thereof.[Page H2878]

item.title: U.S. Commercial Space Launch Competitiveness Act

item.text: Placed on the Union Calendar, Calendar No. 620.
Reported by the Committee on Science, Space, and Technology. H. Rept. 114-797.
Reported by the Committee on Science, Space, and Technology. H. Rept. 114-797.
Ordered to be Reported by Voice Vote.
Committee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held.
Referred to the House Committee on Science, Space, and Technology.

item.title: H.R. 2263, Office of Space Commerce Act
item.description: As ordered reported by the House Committee on Science, Space, and Technology on May 13, 2015

summary.text:
Office of Space Commerce Act

This bill renames the Office of Space Commercialization as the Office of Space Commerce.

The Office of Space Commerce shall:

  • foster the conditions for the economic growth and technological advancement of the U.S. space commerce industry;
  • coordinate space commerce policy issues and actions within the Department of Commerce;
  • represent Commerce in the development of U.S. policies and in negotiations with foreign countries to promote U.S. space commerce;
  • promote the advancement of U.S. geospatial technologies related to space commerce in cooperation with relevant interagency working groups; and
  • support federal government organizations working on Space-Based Positioning, Navigation, and Timing policy.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced. The summary has been expanded because action occurred on the measure.)

Office of Space Commerce Act

(Sec. 2) This bill renames the Office of Space Commercialization as the Office of Space Commerce.

(Sec. 3) The Office of Space Commerce shall:

  • foster the conditions for the economic growth and technological advancement of the U.S. space commerce industry;
  • coordinate space commerce policy issues and actions within the Department of Commerce;
  • represent Commerce in the development of U.S. policies and in negotiations with foreign countries to promote U.S. space commerce;
  • promote the advancement of U.S. geospatial technologies related to space commerce in cooperation with relevant interagency working groups; and
  • support federal government organizations working on Space-Based Positioning, Navigation, and Timing policy.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
